*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: 30. As the owner and/or operator of a retail premises open to the public, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful business invitee, a duty to use reasonable care to maintain the Store and its aisles, shelving, and merchandise in a reasonably safe condition and to protect her from foreseeable risks of harm. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landowners owe reasonable care to lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a Massachusetts case that abolishes the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and holds that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. While the excerpt provided is only Kaplan’s concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the main opinion at 363 Mass. 693, 707 expressly states that occupiers must exercise reasonable care toward lawful visitors, which includes business invitees on premises open to the public. Thus, the case generally supports the proposition that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to a lawful business invitee, though it does not speak specifically about retail aisles and shelving.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "We therefore hold that the distinction between licensees and invitees shall no longer be determinative of the degree of care owed by an occupier of land to a visitor. The proper test is whether, in the management of his property, the occupier has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. In short, the occupier of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors."

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: 30. As the owner and/or operator of a retail premises open to the public, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful business invitee, a duty to use reasonable care to maintain the Store and its aisles, shelving, and merchandise in a reasonably safe condition and to protect her from foreseeable risks of harm. See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (landowners owe reasonable care to lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reiterates the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a common‑law duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, its statement of the landowner‑to‑lawful‑visitor duty is directly consistent with the proposition about a retail premises’ duty to business invitees. The proposition is thus supported, even though Davis is not specifically about a store aisle accident.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988).

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: 31. Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is negligent if it fails to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law and describes the duty as one of “reasonable care,” i.e., the care a reasonable person would exercise. While it does not use the exact phrase “reasonably prudent person,” its articulation of negligence as failure to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances is substantively identical to the proposition. Thus, the case supports the general negligence standard cited.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’”

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: 31. Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is negligent if it fails to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence (duty, breach, causation, damages) and focuses on the plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation, but it does not articulate or define the general Massachusetts negligence standard as ‘failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under like circumstances.’ The quoted language in the proposition does not appear in the decision, nor is an equivalent formulation expressly stated. Thus, Glidden v. Maglio does not itself serve as direct authority for that specific general negligence standard, even though it involves negligence claims.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989).”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: 32. A store owner has a duty to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition in light of the circumstances, including the nature of its business, the arrangement of its merchandise, and the foreseeable behavior of its customers. See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007); *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 377–78 (2010).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states Massachusetts’ general rule that a store owner must maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition “in view of all the circumstances,” and then elaborates that the mode-of-operation analysis requires considering the nature of the business, the foreseeability of customer behavior and recurrent conditions, and whether an ordinarily prudent person would take additional steps to prevent such accidents. Although it does not list “arrangement of its merchandise” verbatim, the court’s discussion of marketing and display of produce and the risks inherent in self-service merchandising plainly encompasses that factor. Thus the case supports the proposition that a store’s duty is defined in light of its business model, merchandising, and foreseeable customer conduct.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). … [T]he trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: 32. A store owner has a duty to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition in light of the circumstances, including the nature of its business, the arrangement of its merchandise, and the foreseeable behavior of its customers. See *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007); *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 377–78 (2010).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos expressly states that the general premises-liability rule of reasonable care applies to hazards from snow and ice just as to other hazards. In doing so, it reaffirms that a property owner must act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances, citing Sheehan and the traditional Restatement § 343 standard, which explicitly includes consideration of the nature of the property and foreseeable risks posed by visitors. Thus, it supports the proposition that a store owner must maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition in light of the circumstances and foreseeable customer behavior.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.proposition: 33. This duty includes, inter alia, the duty to (a) arrange and stack merchandise in a reasonably safe manner; (b) avoid creating unreasonable hazards; (c) inspect the premises with reasonable frequency; and (d) remedy or adequately guard against known or reasonably discoverable dangers. See *Bowers v. P. Wile’s, Inc.*, 454 Mass. 361, 365–66 (2009); *Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 141, 145–46 (2015).
*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.case_name: Boston Gas Co. v. Century Indemnity Co.
*Bowers v. P. Wile\u2019s, Inc.*, 454 Ma.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Bowers v. P. Wile’s, Inc. is about allocation of insurance coverage for long-tail environmental contamination under CGL policies, not premises-liability duties of a store to customers. It does not discuss duties to arrange and stack merchandise safely, avoid hazards, inspect premises, or remedy dangers. Therefore, this citation does not support the specific duty-based negligence proposition for which it is being cited.

*Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. C.raw_text: *Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 141, 145–46 (2015)
*Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. C.proposition: 33. This duty includes, inter alia, the duty to (a) arrange and stack merchandise in a reasonably safe manner; (b) avoid creating unreasonable hazards; (c) inspect the premises with reasonable frequency; and (d) remedy or adequately guard against known or reasonably discoverable dangers. See *Bowers v. P. Wile’s, Inc.*, 454 Mass. 361, 365–66 (2009); *Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 141, 145–46 (2015).
*Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether a guarantor qualifies as a “tenant” entitled to reciprocal attorney’s fees under G. L. c. 186, § 20. It does not address premises liability, duties to arrange or stack merchandise, inspection or remediation of hazards, or any general duty of care on property. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific duty-based proposition cited.
*Thorell v. ADAP, Inc.*, 87 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 20, ‘is limited in scope to equalizing the burden of potential litigation costs where a provision in the lease imposes that burden disproportionately on the tenant,’ … and it is undisputed in this case that Murray was not in possession of the land and not a ‘tenant’ for the purposes of G. L. c. 186, §§ 14 and 15B. … The unambiguous language of § 20 does not evince a Legislative intent to extend reciprocal fee-shifting coverage to guarantors of tenants.”

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.raw_text: *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*, 332 Mass. 560, 562–63 (1955)
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.proposition: 34. A store owner is liable for the foreseeable consequences of its methods of operation and merchandising when those methods create a reasonably foreseeable risk of harm to customers. See *Sheehan*, 448 Mass. at 786–87 (adopting “mode of operation” approach); *Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*, 332 Mass. 560, 562–63 (1955).
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.support_reasoning: Gallagher is a traditional premises-liability/notice case, not a mode-of-operation case. The court analyzes whether the store, exercising reasonable care, should have discovered and removed the spilled ice cream based on its condition and visibility to nearby cashiers, emphasizing constructive notice and reasonable opportunity to remedy a dangerous condition. It does not discuss the store’s merchandising or operational methods as creating a foreseeable risk of harm, nor does it adopt or foreshadow a “mode of operation” doctrine imposing liability without proof of notice.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance… We think that it could be found, however, that the presence of this ice cream on the floor and vestibule of the defendant’s store constituted an appreciable danger to customers. There were three cashiers close by who, when they turned around to get shopping bags, as they frequently did, had a clear view of the floor at the exit door, the threshold, and the vestibule.”

*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.raw_text: *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902 (1987)
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.proposition: 36. A defendant is liable where its negligent acts or omissions are a substantial contributing cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and those harms were a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct. See *Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147; *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902 (1987).
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses foreseeability and proximate cause, but it does not articulate or apply a “substantial contributing cause” standard for negligence liability. Instead, the case focuses on whether the particular harm was reasonably foreseeable at all and concludes there was no duty because the incident was not reasonably foreseeable. Thus, it does not affirm the broader proposition that a defendant is liable when its negligent acts are a substantial contributing cause of foreseeable injuries; rather, it is used here mainly for its foreseeability/duty limitation, not substantial causation language.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.relevant_excerpt: “Proximate cause does not require the particular act which caused the injury to have been foreseen, only that the general character and probability of the injury be foreseeable. Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). But the court will not hold the defendant liable for all possible injury no matter how remote or farfetched. The cause of the injury must be reasonably foreseeable. There is no duty owed when the risk which results in the plaintiff’s injury is not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant.”

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4..proposition: 5. The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, such that this Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: 6. Venue is proper in Middlesex Superior Court, Lowell Division, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, and the Store where the incident occurred is located at 1202 Westford Street, Lowell, Massachusetts 01851. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (comparative negl.proposition: 37. Massachusetts statutes also require a person or entity to exercise reasonable care so as not to inflict injury on others. See, e.g., G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence); G.L. c. 231, § 60D (liability for personal injuries not limited absent statutory provision); and G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (prohibiting unfair or deceptive acts; cited for background of consumer protection duties, though Plaintiff does not assert a G.L. c. 93A claim here).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60D (liability for p.raw_text: G.L. c. 231, § 60D (liability for personal injuries not limited absent statutory provision);
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60D (liability for p.proposition: 37. Massachusetts statutes also require a person or entity to exercise reasonable care so as not to inflict injury on others. G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B,.proposition: 47. Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on any damages awarded from the date this action is commenced.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: 53. Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts rules, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

G.L. c. 261;.proposition: D. Award Plaintiff her allowable costs of suit pursuant to the Massachusetts Rules of Civil Procedure and G.L. c. 261;
